content: * GM files third-largest U.S. bankruptcy ever * U.S. government would own 60 percent of "New GM" * GM out of the Dow; "no longer suitable" for NYSE listing * Judge clears sale of Chrysler assets to Fiat-led group * Obama hails Chrysler sale approval Following the bankruptcy filing, GM shares were removed from the Dow Jones industrial average .DJI and delisted by the New York Stock Exchange as "no longer suitable for listing." Chrysler's bankruptcy, also financed by the U.S. Treasury, has been widely seen as a test run for the much bigger and more complex reorganization of GM. President Barack Obama said that concessions by labor and creditors achieved a viable and achievable plan for GM to complete its restructuring and have a chance to succeed. "I am absolutely confident that if well-managed, a new GM will emerge that can ... out-compete automakers around the world and that can once again be an integral part of America's economic future," Obama said. "The immediate implication is that the companies are going to get smaller and so market share is up for grabs, which means that rivals like Toyota (7203.T), Honda (7267.T), Nissan (7201.T) and Hyundai (005380.KS) are going to gain share." Indeed, one of GM's major challenges will be to create a streamlined offering of vehicles that are affordable, stylish and fuel-efficient. "People forget that very high oil prices were one of the triggers for this recession," Daniel Yergin, chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said at the Reuters Global Energy Summit on Monday. "General Motors was thrown on its back by what happened at the gasoline pump." "http://www.reuters.com/article/bankruptcyNews/idUSN0139857520090601" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

"http://www.reuters.com/article/bankruptcyNews/idUSN0139857520090601" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
title: New GM, Chrysler sale cleared

Chrysler's bankruptcy, also financed by the U.S. Treasury, has been widely seen as a test run for the much bigger and more complex reorganization of GM. "I am absolutely confident that if well-managed, a new GM will emerge that can ... out-compete automakers around the world and that can once again be an integral part of America's economic future," Obama said. Indeed, one of GM's major challenges will be to create a streamlined offering of vehicles that are affordable, stylish and fuel-efficient. "People forget that very high oil prices were one of the triggers for this recession," Daniel Yergin, chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said at the Reuters Global Energy Summit on Monday. "General Motors was thrown on its back by what happened at the gasoline pump." "http://www.reuters.com/article/bankruptcyNews/idUSN0139857520090601" And by the actions of previous administrations that didn't think fully, when it came to the economic survival of the nation, by running up astronomical debt, trade deals that would off shore industry, thus loosing American jobs and thus decreasing the money available to American blue and white collar workers to buy American manufactured or at least assembled automobiles and trucks... This can be traced all the way back to the first great economic depression in the 1930s and deficit spending by successive administrations... Finally culminating in unfair and unbalanced trade deals... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

title: New GM, Chrysler sale cleared

content: quote: Originally posted by Anbar7: Following the bankruptcy filing, GM shares were removed from the Dow Jones industrial average .DJI and delisted by the New York Stock Exchange as "no longer suitable for listing." Is this going to help the stock market now that it isn't in there or is this going to hurt more? Guess we will have to wait and see. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
